Johannes \"Jojo\" Betzler.Action: Swears devotion and readiness to sacrifice himself for Adolf Hitler.
Dresses meticulously and prepares himself carefully for his Jungvolk training, showing attention to detail and discipline.
Takes a deep breath and solemnly recites a pledge of devotion, indicating seriousness but also nervousness.
Responds nervously but loyally to imaginary Adolf, smiles and feels better after encouragement.
Recites aggressive Nazi affirmations enthusiastically, adopting violent and exclusionary ideology.
Expresses nervousness and lacks self-confidence, struggles with simple tasks like tying shoelaces, but tries to rally himself with encouragement from imaginary friend.
Listens to and responds positively to encouragement, showing willingness to try despite insecurities.
Quickly learns and enthusiastically repeats the 'Heil Hitler' chant along with his imaginary friend Adolf, showing eagerness and ability to imitate and follow instructions.
Runs confidently through town greeting locals with the Nazi salute and chant, demonstrating social confidence in his environment.
Eagerly engages with his best friend Yorki and other kids in the Hitler Youth camp, indicating social competence in peer interactions.
Inspects and admires the new Deutsches Jungvolk knives, showing attentiveness and appreciation for important tools.
Smiles at Yorki in excitement about the training activities at the Hitler Youth camp.
Participates in violent and aggressive activities like knife throwing and war games eagerly.
Jojo participates eagerly in the Hitler Youth training activities, showing enthusiasm and smiles especially with Yorki, indicating motivation and willingness to learn.
Attempts knife throwing but fails repeatedly and causes an accident where a knife ricochets and lodges in another kid’s thigh.
Jojo fires his rifle but is startled by the loudness and drops the weapon.
Joins in the bonfire book burning with enthusiasm, follows the group's hateful ideology.
Sits quietly and does not oppose the hateful lessons and propaganda taught to children.
Together with Yorki, shares a moment inspecting their knives, showing camaraderie and friendship.
Jojo and Yorki are taken prisoner instantly in the war game, showing inability to avoid capture or anticipate enemy moves.
Jojo participates in the book burning ritual, bringing a small pile of books he found on the list, showing some initiative and adherence to instructions.
Jojo lies awake inspecting his new DJ knives, showing curiosity and focus on his equipment, possibly indicating attentiveness and preparation.
Displays confident bravado in imagining fighting with a DJ Knife and taking down 20 enemies while laughing.
Repeats a simplistic, naïve motto 'Live Faithfully, Fight Bravely, and Die Laughing' without deeper strategic thought.
Fails to question or critically evaluate the racist and propaganda-driven statements about Jews, parroting childish and inaccurate beliefs.
Stares quietly at the sky and whispers a sentimental hope that his father returns soon, showing emotional sensitivity but passivity in a difficult situation.
Refuses to kill the rabbit despite pressure and peer chanting, shows hesitation and empathy to the animal
Uses an excuse (allergy) to avoid killing the rabbit
Raises hand indicating willingness to kill but hesitates and shows discomfort when asked to actually kill the rabbit.
Refuses to kill the rabbit citing an excuse (allergic to fur) and ultimately drops it instead of following through.
Stands up for his father, insists his father is brave despite insults.
Tries to save the bunny from being killed.
Feels deep sadness and sobs alone after being humiliated and taunted.
Runs away to avoid further taunting rather than retaliating aggressively.
Stands up after being kicked and taunted, then runs away to escape ridicule.
Defends his father as brave and fighting, contradicting others’ insults.
Fails to kill the rabbit when ordered to, showing inability or hesitation.
Sobs alone in the woods after being mocked, showing emotional vulnerability.
Tries to wink back at Adolf Hitler despite being awkward and uncertain.
Tells Yorki he was doing push-ups to cover up his emotional vulnerability when suspected of crying.
Avoids directly explaining his feelings to Yorki and says 'Never mind' when questioned.
Barges into a dangerous situation by grabbing a grenade and recklessly throwing it, putting himself and others at risk.
Engages in playful, enthusiastic shouting ("Jojo rabbit! Jojo rabbit! Hunting carrots") showing a childlike friendliness and energy.
Jerks a grenade from their teacher's hand impulsively and pulls the pin, then throws it recklessly, causing an explosion at their feet.
Rushes impulsively into a dangerous situation without proper understanding or caution.
Shows lack of situational awareness and poor judgment by mishandling a grenade during a supervised lesson.
Reaches out to his mother despite his injuries, showing vulnerability and connection.
Expresses self-doubt about being able to join Hitler’s SS Guard, indicating insecurity and desire for approval.
Tries to tie his bootlaces independently despite physical difficulty, showing perseverance but also seeking normalcy and self-sufficiency.
Struggles to tie his bootlaces with only one good hand, requiring assistance from his mother.
Shows determination by stating 'I need to be better' despite his physical limitations.
Accepts help from his mother to overcome a practical challenge (tying boots).
Reluctantly agrees to leave the house despite feeling self-conscious and scared.
Plays along with Rosie's playful encouragement and imagination (pretending the biscuit is a shield, earring, etc.).
Hesitates and expresses fear about going outside, feeling self-conscious and worried about looking stupid.
Eventually agrees to go out despite his fears, showing a willingness to try and push through his anxiety.
Smiles and plays along with Rosie’s imaginative encouragement, indicating a flexible and adaptive mindset.
Steals a hand-grenade resulting in injury to himself and causing his mother to confront and reprimand an officer.
Steals a hand grenade and injures himself.
Despite injury and trouble caused, is accepted into the Hitler Youth office and given a role to help him feel included.
Pins up Hitler propaganda posters without visible enthusiasm, follows orders obediently.
Turns on heels and leaves quickly after being given a task, showing limited emotional engagement.
Accepts the small task of delivering propaganda and conscriptions and commits to executing orders.
Pins up propaganda posters in a stoic and focused manner, demonstrating seriousness.
Takes a moment to look at a photo of his sister Inga and smiles before putting it back
Reacts with fear and fright upon discovering the hidden girl in the secret room, then freezes and cautiously watches
Ignores the bullying and ridicule from Hans and the other boys chanting and mocking him
Pastes propaganda and public announcements around town, showing dedication to his duties.
Carefully searches his sister's room and notices a thin cut in the wallpaper, demonstrating observational skills.
Uses his knife skillfully to pry open the secret door, showing practical problem-solving ability.
Screams with fright and drops his knife upon seeing the girl, reacting emotionally rather than confidently.
Immediately runs away in fear when Elsa appears and is frightened by her presence.
Refers to Elsa with fear and aggression, telling her to get out of his house.
Despite initial fear, does not physically retaliate or harm Elsa when threatened with a knife; remains mostly defensive and fearful.
Shows fear and hesitation when Elsa threatens him with a knife but does not retaliate violently, indicating a reluctance to harm.
Uses humor and imagination (pretend armor and playful knocking) to approach Elsa, signaling attempts at connection despite fear.
Rejects Adolf's offered cigarette, indicating a desire not to engage in negative habits despite stressful situation.
Considers and attempts to communicate with Elsa rather than threatening or expelling her, showing tolerance and an effort to establish trust.
Tells Elsa she should find somewhere else to live, despite her holding a knife and confronting him.
Expresses frustration about offered cigarettes and shows stress about the situation.
Stands up verbally to Elsa despite danger, shows initial bravery and determination.
Fails to effectively handle or control the situation with Elsa, gets physically overpowered and knocked down.
Expresses uncertainty and confusion about how to handle the knife situation, lacks clear problem-solving.
Participates actively in brainstorming with Adolf, trying to seek solutions.
Staring into space, appears worried and reflective after conversation with imaginary Adolf, listens quietly to his mother Rosie’s concern and care (not shown as rejecting or dismissive).
Internal conflict and worry shown by untied shoes and introspection, indicating vulnerability and openness to care.
Listens to Adolf (his imaginary friend) giving tactical advice and tries to apply it by considering mind games and manipulation strategies.
Sits staring into space worried, distracted, and loses track of time, showing a lack of focus.
Has untied shoelaces repeatedly, showing carelessness in small practical matters.
Tells his mother he heard noises and shows concern about rats in the attic, promising to watch out for them to avoid getting sick.
Asks sincerely if his mother misses his father and others, showing openness and emotional connection.
Willingly interacts warmly with his mother during bedtime routine, accepting her care and trust.
Attempts to return a wink to Rosie despite initial failure.
Shown as a fanatic by Rosie, hard to reason with and rigid in beliefs.
Tries to wink like Rosie but struggles and needs her help to succeed.
Punches his pillow in anger and dives back onto his bed, showing frustration and internal struggle.
Observes wounded soldiers around him without hostile reaction, suggesting possible empathy or tolerance.
Punches his pillow and angrily dives back onto his bed when frustrated.
Endures physical rehabilitation exercises despite obvious pain, attempting to regain mobility.
Remains lying down on his back passively after therapy session instead of actively engaging or showing initiative.
Nods silently as his mother kisses his head goodbye.
Asks Klenzendorf what to do if he sees a Jew, showing curiosity and internal conflict.
Avoids lying or implicating anyone despite pressure, indicates uncertainty and thoughtfulness.
Considers the harsh consequences explained about Jews and helpers with visible discomfort.
Lies down and watches his mother's shoes spin, showing quiet observation and calm in a tense moment.
Limping but still approaches authority figures (Klenzendorf and Finkel) and initiates conversation.
Asks direct and serious questions about Jews and what to do if he sees one, showing curiosity and willingness to understand complex, dangerous situations.
Admits uncertainty about being able to identify a Jew, showing self-awareness of his limitations.
Gulps nervously when hearing about consequences for Jews and helpers, indicating fear and possibly a lack of confidence in handling the gravity of the situation.
Negotiates a 'Mexican stalemate' with Elsa, aiming to protect both of their interests.
Sets conditions for Elsa to stay, showing cautious trust and a desire to learn about her.
Uses a soup ladle as a symbolic weapon but approaches Elsa with humor and openness.
Insists Elsa not sit on his sister’s bed, showing protective care for his family.
Initially insults Elsa by denying her personhood and using derogatory Nazi ideology.
Stops writing and listens attentively when Elsa reveals vulnerabilities (allergic to food).
Ends the interaction respectfully, suggests continuing the conversation tomorrow and leaves without further cruelty.
Responds to Rosie’s return with awkward silence but does not lash out or show anger.
Listens quietly to Rosie and participates in shared quiet moments despite tension.
Does not intervene when Rosie burns pieces of paper, indicating tacit tolerance or acceptance.
Maintains composure when Rosie arrives home unexpectedly, does not panic despite Adolf's reaction.
Does not react or intervene when Adolf behaves irrationally and screams about Rosie burning something, showing limited situational control.
Quietly allows Rosie and himself to share an awkward but meaningful moment, showing emotional intelligence and patience.
Does not vocalize concerns or questions about what Rosie is burning or about Adolf's suspicious behavior, missing an opportunity to take charge.
Shows concern for Rosie by noticing she isn’t eating and offers to eat her food.
Makes self-deprecating comments about his face looking 'like a street map'.
Abruptly expresses resentment toward Rosie by saying 'Instead I’m stuck with you.'
Openly admits he misses his father and is emotionally vulnerable about it.
Uses sarcasm and self-deprecating humor to express frustration and self-image issues, e.g., calling himself 'a deformed kid with nothing to live for' and joking about his face.
Attempts to lighten tense moments with humor and playful threats to eat his mother's food, showing social awareness.
Engages in emotionally charged dialogue with his mother, revealing vulnerability and limited emotional control.
Does not challenge or redirect his mother's resignation and self-destructive behavior, indicating passivity.
Nods in agreement and accepts the responsibility to take care of his mother while his father is away.
Initially shocked and taken aback by his mother's angry outburst, sitting back quietly without protesting or reacting aggressively.
Responds positively and obediently to his mother’s encouragement and invitation to dance, showing emotional adaptability and openness.
Presses Elsa for personal information despite her reluctance, mocks her boyfriend and displays dismissive attitude.
Expresses general curiosity and tries to build connection by asking Elsa about her family and background.
Tries to engage Elsa by asking about Jews and her family, attempting to gain background information.
Mispronounces words and shows ignorance about Rilke (a well-known poet), indicating gaps in knowledge.
Dismisses Elsa's story and relationship with Nathan in a childish and derogatory manner.
Persists in conversation despite Elsa's negative attitude and resistance.
Rolls his eyes dismissively when Elsa talks about love.
Takes a moment, seemingly under Elsa's spell before breaking out of it.
Stares at his drawing after Elsa points to his forehead and says 'That's where we live.'
Secretly takes a poetry book from the library, showing a personal interest in deeper thought.
Finds a specific book (Rilke: Poems and Essays) in a sparse town library and secretly takes it.
Rolls his eyes and dismisses Elsa's emotional perspective on love quickly as 'Ridiculous.'
Fails to grasp or accept Elsa's metaphor that Jews 'live in his head,' reflected in his drawing and reaction.
Reads Nathan's hurtful letter aloud to Elsa despite her distress, causing her to retreat upset.
Knocks gently on Elsa’s door and cautiously reads a second letter from Nathan, showing hesitance and care.
Calls Elsa 'a remarkable young man' and acknowledges her bravery, showing respect and kindness toward Elsa.
Tries to communicate with Elsa despite her closed door, displaying concern for her well-being.
Reads the letters carefully to Elsa despite the sensitive content, showing emotional resilience and honesty.
Gently knocks and communicates with Elsa without forcing her to open the door, respecting her boundaries.
Forgets there was a second letter initially, indicating some forgetfulness.
Engages in playful and friendly banter with Elsa about musicians and artists.
Shows a brusque attitude by saying 'There’s no time for romance, we're at war.' to Rosie.
Expresses skepticism and self-deprecation about love, admitting 'I wouldn’t even know it if I saw it.'
Engages in a playful intellectual exchange naming composers and historical figures, showing some memory and cultural knowledge.
Dismisses the idea of romance during wartime as unimportant, showing a limited emotional intelligence or narrow focus.
Fails to notice his shoelaces are undone despite being told, indicating a lack of attention to detail.
Laughs and plays with his mother even when embarrassed about shoelaces tied together; tries to chase her playfully.
Responds with playful teasing ('Don’t believe her!') when his mother pretends he's drunk.
Engages with his mother during a warm, affectionate moment at the river despite conflicting views on war and fun.
Trips over shoelaces tied together and needs help to get up, struggles momentarily but laughs it off.
Plays and laughs with his mother despite minor clumsiness, showing good spirit and resilience.
Attempts to chase his mother after shoelaces prank, showing determination and responsiveness.
Pedals away on bicycle with Rosie chasing him playfully
Joins Rosie in waving to wounded soldiers, bringing a smile to their faces
Sighs after joke about Nathan, shows vulnerability
Shows interest and attentiveness when Elsa starts telling a story
Watches Elsa draw attentively and engages with her imaginatively despite his young age, sharing in creative play.
Makes a hurtful generalization about Jews as loving ugliness based on Nazi propaganda teachings.
Catches a glimpse of his own scarred face and registering his own perceived 'ugliness' without bitterness, showing some self-awareness.
States he was checking to make sure Elsa was still alive, not out of genuine care but to avoid having a dead person in his house.
Actively engages in drawing and writing details quickly and enthusiastically; processes information from Elsa about creatures and incorporates it creatively.
Shows curiosity and critical thinking by questioning Elsa about specifics (horns, minds of Germans).
Associates school-taught prejudice (Jews love ugliness) with his own scarred appearance, reflects on it noticeably.
Does not oppose or critically challenge Elsa’s fantastical claims, potentially indicating naivety or acceptance without skepticism.
Admits feeling uncomfortable about the time others are spending together.
Engages playfully and sincerely with his imaginary Adolf Hitler, showing openness and admiration.
Listens attentively to advice from his imaginary Adolf, processes it with admiration and willingness to apply it.
Engages in self-directed internal dialogue and reflection about his relationships and thoughts.
Shows uncertainty and awkwardness in social or emotional situations implied by discomfort about time spent between others.
Looks at himself in the mirror with a scowl and turns out the light, showing a moment of self-reflection and vulnerability.
Looks in the mirror and scowls at himself, then confidently turns out the light and prepares for the next part of his day.
Walks into the Hitler Youth office calmly and purposefully, indicating confidence in his role and actions.
Engages with authority figure Klenzendorf by asking about Jews, showing curiosity though influenced by propaganda.
Secretly pockets coloured pencils from the desk while Klenzendorf isn't looking.
Asks Klenzendorf about available jobs proactively, demonstrating initiative and willingness to contribute.
Responds briefly and passively when asked how things are going at home ('It's ok').
Politely asks the old woman for metal donations in a friendly and earnest manner.
Observes his mother’s secret anti-Nazi actions quietly without exposing or confronting her.
Embraces his old friend Yorki warmly, showing genuine affection and friendliness.
Constructs a creative cardboard robot to collect metal for the war effort, demonstrating initiative and resourcefulness.
Engages with townspeople politely and persistently to gather metal, showing social and persuasive skills.
Fails to immediately recognize or question the subversive activity of his mother distributing anti-Nazi flyers, indicating limited perceptiveness.
Observes without revealing himself while his mother conducts secret resistance activity, indicating observational skills but also passivity.
Admits his feelings of nervousness and love while watching Elsa brush her hair.
Insists on being a Nazi despite Elsa telling him he is not a real Nazi.
Shuffles nervously and opens Elsa's bedroom door, showing hesitance and vulnerability.
Acknowledges the illegality and social complications of Nazi and Jewish interaction, showing some awareness of reality.
Self-identifies as a Nazi despite internal doubt and contradictory feelings, showing confusion rather than confident identity.
Rolls eyes and refuses to reconsider his views when challenged by Elsa, indicating stubbornness and lack of reflective thinking.
Exhibits nervousness and internal conflict around Elsa, indicating emotional vulnerability but also self-awareness.
Warns Elsa to stay away from windows to protect her from danger.
Greets Gestapo agents with repeated 'Heil Hitler' salutations despite the tension.
Opens the door calmly for Gestapo agents and participates in their ritual greeting without panicking.
Warns Elsa to hide quietly when danger approaches.
Does not attempt to mislead or manipulate the Gestapo during their inspection, staying neutral.
Responds politely and respectfully to Deertz's questions and inspection, remains composed under pressure.
Does not reveal his mother's whereabouts or activities despite the intrusive search.
Volunteers at the Hitlerjugend office and shows commitment as noted by Deertz and Klenzendorf.
Unable to account for his mother's whereabouts clearly, seeming uncertain.
Responds directly and succinctly to questions from officers but avoids elaboration.
Does not appear to keep or use the DJ knife, a symbol of commitment or readiness in the Hitlerjugend, showing a lack of preparedness.
Is wide-eyed and panicked when confronted by Elsa and the agents, tries to stall awkwardly.
Attempts to participate in the Heil Hitler salute to avoid suspicion.
Feels nervous and guilty when Deertz discovers his anti-Semitic book, indicating sensitivity and insecurity.
Possesses and supports a hateful book targeting Jews, showing internalized prejudice.
Jojo gulps nervously when Deertz notices his anti-Semitic book, showing fear and lack of confidence in a tense situation.
Does not intervene or try to influence the conversation when Elsa is being interrogated and papers examined, indicating passivity.
Shows fantastical drawings that include magical worlds and animals, expressing creativity and imagination.
Looks sheepishly at Elsa when asked about Nathan, showing vulnerability and discomfort.
Remains silent and watches officers laugh at his drawings, including violent and hostile content aimed at Nathan.
Creates detailed, imaginative drawings and writings for the 'exposé' demonstrating creativity and imaginative thinking.
Responds sheepishly and avoids explaining the character Nathan when questioned, showing evasiveness and lack of confidence.
Listens quietly and complies when told to stay home and look after his family and the knife, showing obedience but lack of initiative.
Offers to protect Elsa by agreeing to let her assume Inga's identity and supports her despite the risks involved.
Responds with silence and allows Elsa to isolate herself after she rejects his friendship because she sees them as enemies (Jew and Nazi).
Smiles and attentively follows a butterfly in the town square, showing gentle curiosity and sensitivity.
Visits the gallows, becomes distressed and tries to care for his mother’s shoes, attempting to tie her untied lace.
Sits quietly beneath the bodies at dusk, indicating a moment of solemn reflection and emotional processing.
Enters Elsa’s hideout tearfully holding a knife and stabs her just below the collarbone.
Tears streaming down his face, struggling with stabbing Elsa but shows vulnerability rather than cruelty.
Collapses on the floor and shares a quiet, meaningful look with Elsa, indicating connection and recognition.
Expresses feelings of being hated and as the enemy, showing emotional honesty and internal conflict.
Feels he has nothing and no one left, demonstrating vulnerability and openness.
Attempts to stab Elsa but is too weak to drive the knife all the way in, struggles but finally collapses.
Sits with Elsa on the rooftop, listens carefully to her explanation about his mother and war, shows emotional awareness and reflection.
Barters with a local peasant for old vegetables.
Reads Elsa a letter and pins her drawings on his bedroom wall alongside his own.
Moves toward chaos to check on Yorki and reconnects with him, showing concern.
Jojo barters with a local peasant for old vegetables.
Jojo pins Elsa's drawings on the wall alongside his pictures of Hitler, showing an organized approach to keeping memories.
Jojo moves towards the chaos and explosion rather than fleeing with civilians.
Jojo reads Elsa a 'Nathan letter' and spends time interacting with her patiently.
Jojo sees Yorki trip and cause an accidental rocket launcher discharge.
Carries ammo to help gunners alongside Yorki
Engages in conversation with Yorki about the situation and rumors
Receives ammo from Yorki and helps by carrying it to gunners.
Engages in conversation reflecting confusion and naivety about war and enemies (e.g., believing absurd rumors about Russians and Englishmen).
Acts calmly and keeps moving forward despite chaotic and dangerous environment.
Seems unsure or shocked hearing that Hitler is dead, unable to immediately accept or process it.
Drops everything and runs off during the tank attack, showing instinct for self-preservation but no indication of protecting others.
Moves through battlefield passing desperate women, children, and elderly who are failing to defend themselves, without shown attempt to help them.
Watches the retreat of German soldiers, sees chaos and cries but does not intervene directly.
Hears a whimper, lifts an old door to rescue Fraulein Rahm who is dying under rubble.
Observes scenes of desperation and distress without displaying hostility or aggression.
Follows Klenzendorf and Finkel wearing his altered uniform with sequins and tassels, showing creativity but taking cover and observing the retreating soldiers.
Ducks into a doorway and hides in a hole during the chaotic retreat.
Walks through ruins and, upon hearing a whimper, lifts an old door to find and attempt to help Fraulein Rahm.
Unable to lift the building off Fraulein Rahm as she dies, showing limits to his physical capability but also compassion.
Approaches Captain Klenzendorf with concern and seeks information about Fraulein Rahm.
Stands silently while Klenzendorf is abused by Russian soldier, showing no violent reaction but enduring the moment.
Approaches Captain Klenzendorf and seeks information about the situation despite fear and confusion.
Is disheveled and looks frightened, showing vulnerability and lack of composed confidence in a crisis.
Allows himself to be led and shoved without resistance or attempting to influence the situation or escape.
Helps Gogo, who defends Klenzendorf despite the soldier's hostility.
Gets pushed out roughly by soldier but gets up and dusts himself off, showing resilience.
Expresses concern for Elsa potentially leaving after the war ends.
Ponders confusedly about the war ending and his situation without hostility towards others.
Gets to his feet and dusts himself off after being pushed out and knocked down.
Looks confused and doesn't understand what's happening around him.
Pauses and contemplates after realizing Elsa may leave, showing awareness and thoughtfulness.
Wanders slowly up to his house and pauses before entering, indicating hesitation and uncertainty.
Thinks carefully before deciding that Elsa can't leave to keep her safe, showing thoughtfulness and caution.
Uses a fake letter to encourage Elsa to escape, demonstrating creativity, planning, and resourcefulness.
Stands alone reflecting on photos and his book, showing introspection but some hesitation or emotional conflict.
Reassures Elsa by calling himself her 'younger brother' to build trust and offers to help her escape Nazi Germany.
Decides to leave the house with Elsa to help her escape despite danger.
Confronts Adolf and calmly tries to explain his change of heart and loyalty to Elsa.
Expresses love for Elsa openly despite risks.
Organizes a plan to help Elsa escape Nazi Germany and instructs her to get her things together to leave.
Shows emotional intelligence and maturity by honestly confronting his conflicting feelings in dialogue with Adolf.
Despite Adolf blocking his path and demanding answers, Jojo remains firm and assertive about leaving, demonstrating confident decision-making.
Rejects Adolf's demands and insults, refuses to comply with hateful ideology.
Kicks Adolf (his imaginary friend) hard in the balls and sends him flying through the window.
Ties Elsa’s shoelaces carefully, prompting a small smile from her.
Screws up the swastika armband and throws it on the ground, rejecting Adolf's demand decisively.
Kicks Adolf (his imaginary Hitler) hard enough to send him flying through the window, demonstrating courage and assertiveness.
Ties Elsa’s shoelaces attentively, showing sensitivity and practical skill.
Bends down and ties Elsa’s shoelaces, showing care and attentiveness.
Winks reassuringly and says 'Extremely' to Elsa's question about danger, using humor to comfort her.
Accepts Elsa’s slap without anger, acknowledging he probably deserved it.
Dances slowly and intimately with Elsa, sharing a moment of sincere connection.
Bends down and ties Elsa’s shoelaces carefully before they leave the house.
Responds confidently when Elsa asks if it is dangerous outside by giving a perfect wink and stating 'Extremely.'
After Elsa slaps him, he acknowledges it maturely and questions what to do next.
Joins Elsa in rhythmic swaying and dancing despite uncertain circumstances.
